info.game_comments: Battle of the Decades: The 1980s game 2.

(1, 1).clue: The Suez Canal is opened & the Emancipation Proclamation is issued

(2, 1).clue: Part I of a trilogy:A gold mockingjay pin

(3, 1).clue: In 2012 this Portland native revealed that Springfield, home of "The Simpsons", is named after Springfield, Oregon

(4, 1).clue: "You're saying I could be stuck in Wichita?" asks Steve Martin in this film

(5, 1).clue: In 2008 Toyota ended this company's 77-year reign as the world's top automaker

(1, 2).clue: The first successful human heart transplant & the invention of 8-track tapes

(2, 2).clue: A sci-fi novel:A man in a newspaper suit is on fire

(3, 2).clue: An annual 10k road race in Coos Bay honors this track star who died young

(4, 2).clue: "Sixteen Candles" was written with a picture of this Hughes muse on John's bulletin board

(5, 2).clue: Since 1957 Standard & Poor's has had an index of this many stocks

(6, 2).clue: 5-letter word for the last newspaper edition published on a day

(1, 3).clue: Ray Kroc opens the first franchised McDonald's

(2, 3).clue: A 1920s classic:A woman's eyes in which the irises are reclining nudes over a metropolitan skyline at night

(3, 3).clue: Her characters Beezus & Ramona Quimby live on Klickitat Street, a real street near her childhood home in Portland

(4, 3).clue: This film takes place entirely on a single Saturday in a high school

(5, 3).clue: In 1967 this company's holdings included 2 peewee Nebraska insurance companies: now it owns GEICO

(6, 3).clue: In logic it's a result inferred from the premises of an argument

(2, 4).clue: From 1969:The puppeteer's hand holds the control piece, with the strings attached to the title

(3, 4).clue: Presented by his foundation, "the Oscars of the food world" are named for this late chef & author

(4, 4).clue: Danny DeVito was considered for the title role of "Uncle Buck", but this man got the part

(5, 4).clue: In 2013 Facebook dangled $3 billion in cash in front of this photo-messaging company, which said no

(6, 4).clue: A certain cyborg, or the dividing line between the illuminated & unilluminated part of the Moon

(1, 5).clue: Leonardo da Vinci paints "The Last Supper"

(2, 5).clue: An iconic cover for an iconic novel:The title in yellow & a line drawing of a carousel horse dominating a slice of New York City

(3, 5).clue: A Pasadena, California museum bears the name of this Oregon-born industrialist & art collector

(4, 5).clue: 1988 film about a pair of newlyweds preparing for parenthood

(5, 5).clue: This giant Peoria-based company purchased ERA Mining Machinery in 2012

(6, 5).clue: It comes between "you" & "me" in a Tom Cruise movie line

(1, 1).clue: To this state whose motto is "Industry"

(2, 1).clue: Born in the year 2230, he was the son of an Earth mother & a Vulcan diplomat

(3, 1).clue: This synonym for "insolvent" comes partly from a Latin word for "broken"

(4, 1).clue: E=mc2 was conceived by this man

(5, 1).clue: A surrealist word game produced the phrase "cadavre exquis", which lives on in the name of the journal "Exquisite" this

(6, 1).clue: If it's big, this yummy creature may be called a prawn

(1, 2).clue: To the Black Sea port of Odessa in this country

(2, 2).clue: Of the 6 main characters on "Friends", these 2 were brother & sister

(3, 2).clue: If you grasp all the symbols seen here at a glance, this field must be your hobby

(4, 2).clue: The "E" stands for energy, particularly this type, from the Greek for "moving"

(5, 2).clue: He painted a pipe with the baffling caption "This is not a pipe"

(6, 2).clue: Clarinetist Dave Tarras was "the king of" this music style of Ashkenazi Jews

(1, 3).clue: To Lucknow, capital of this Indian province

(2, 3).clue: TV viewers are keen on Megan Boone as FBI profiler Liz Keen & James Spader as Red Reddington on this drama

(3, 3).clue: In this type of composition, like Brahms' Opus 79, the "H" is silent

(4, 3).clue: E=mc2 refuted the old laws of this "of mass" & "of energy"--m & E aren't fixed in total quantity but can be converted

(5, 3).clue: This French surrealist made the 1946 film "Beauty and the Beast"

(6, 3).clue: This title TV guy made the confession "Squidward, I used your clarinet to unclog my toilet!"

(1, 4).clue: To this Texas city that Vice President John Nance Garner called home

(2, 4).clue: Before there was Castle, there was Jessica Fletcher, who penned mysteries & solved them on this series

(3, 4).clue: Flecks of fat in a steak

(4, 4).clue: The equation would never have made it big in its original version, which was conceived as the equivalent m = this

(5, 4).clue: Surrealism popped up in '80s music as this band's song "Debaser" took off from Bunuel's film "Un chien andalou"

(6, 4).clue: Tilapia is known in Israel as this apostle's fish; tradition holds he caught one & found a coin in its mouth

(1, 5).clue: To this African river formed bv the confluence of the Bomu & the Uele

(2, 5).clue: On BBC America, Idris Elba plays this brilliant but self-destructive detective

(3, 5).clue: A light-giving celestial body, or someone eminent in his or her field

(4, 5).clue: The equation's insight into the behavior of light was an extension of the work of this 3-named Scot around 1870

(5, 5).clue: "Dog Barking at the Moon" is by this countryman of Picasso & Dali who ran with the Surrealists in the 1920s

(6, 5).clue: Thrilled by the recently invented instrument, he wrote the quintet heard here

(0, 0).clue: Readers' letters to this author about her 1948 short story asked where the title event was held & if they could go & watch
